description.narrative: (Ghana): USAID "WASH for Health" supports the Government of Ghana to effectively plan, design, and manage the construction of water and sanitation facilities in six regions. Eight-five percent of Ghanaians lack access to improved sanitation, contributing to disease and poor nutrition in the country. Using fiscal year 2018 funds, USAID will continue supporting community participation and ownership of water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) activities. The Community Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) approach engages and mobilizes communities through social and behavior change communication. Assistance will support the drilling and rehabilitation of mechanical and manual boreholes, the construction of small-town water systems, and the introduction of rainwater harvesting in community-based health facilities, clinics, and schools. USAID will continue supporting the CLTS approach by increasing the reach of Duraplast, USAID created Digni-Loo latrine. This public-private partnership aligns with Ghana's "Beyond Aid" vision by engaging local manufacturers, and ensures country ownership and sustainability while offering a quality, low cost sanitation option. Further, USAID will leverage partnerships with Rotary International and the Coca-Cola Company to construct additional boreholes and create small-town water schemes. The range of interventions through this activity contributes to the elimination of open defecation and promotes hygiene and handwashing, thus preventing the spread of waterborne diseases. .. .
